title: river-tyne-exercise-stations-haddington-removed
story: Discussions took place surrounding the future of the green metal bars beside the River Tyne in Haddington at the end of last year.Now, after consultation with Haddingtonrsquos community council, East Lothian Council has agreed to remove the exercise stations ndash with the possibility of installing some in Neilson Park instead.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoThe Tyne walkway exercise stations were erected in early , following discussions with local stakeholders, including Haddington and District Community Council and Friends of the River Tyne group, to provide opportunities for people to improve their physical activity levels, with support from the Ageing Well initiative and local health professionals.ldquoThe use of these stations has continued to be monitored and it has been agreed to remove them from current locations with a view to potentially relocating some within Neilson Park or at East Lothian Community Hospital.Last November, community councillors questioned the future of the stations, which were described as ldquoeyesores.The  stations ndash a series of basic metal structures ndash were created, stretching from The Maltings to The Sands, with funding coming from Paths for All, Ageing Well and the community council.Shortly before Christmas, the community council was asked to vote on whether the stations had a future beside Haddingtonrsquos river. Unanimously, they agreed the stations should be removed.Chris McEwan, chairman of the group, said: ldquoThe feelings from the public are the majority of them are thinking the exercise stations are a waste of time and effort.ldquoThere are a few people who have used them but the majority are saying to remove them.Members highlighted that the exercise stations that were installed did not match what had originally been suggested five years ago.Each station along the route is supposed to have an A sign, with a drawing and text explaining how to use the equipment.However, when they were revealed, a number of members of public were unimpressed with the new additions.They were described as ldquoabsurd and ldquougly, as well as ldquodefacing the natural beauty of the landscape.A sheet of paper was tied to a tree near the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre urging members of the public to contact East Lothian Council so that the ldquoill-judged project be removed.Mr McEwan highlighted that the idea of moving them to Neilson Park had also been suggested.He questioned how users of the park, which is home to the townrsquos cricket, rugby and tennis clubs, would feel about the exercise stations being introduced.Fellow community councillor Therese Laing highlighted that exercise stations had found success where.She said: ldquoWe used them in Germany years ago and it was great fun.ldquoThey were dferent things, not just the bars.ldquoThere is a park in Edinburgh with quite exciting ones but the ones round the Tyne are definitely not.

title: cafe-offices-plan-approved-longniddry-south-housing-development
story: Work to construct hundreds of new homes on the southern side of the East Coast Mainline at Longniddry has been ongoing for nearly a year.Now, a second application, which includes a cafe and offices, has been approved by East Lothian Council.A spokesperson for the Wemyss and March Estates said: ldquoWe are delighted to have received permission for the conversion of the existing buildings to business units at Longniddry Farm.ldquoThese can provide space for commercial uses, such as for a cafe and offices, and we will now start preparing for the conversion and marketing of the units.ldquoIn addition to much-needed new housing, we wanted to make sure that there were tangible benefits for the existing residents of Longniddry, such as employment opportunities, and that these are fully integrated with the existing village.ldquoThrough this permission, we can continue to turn our initial vision into a reality, creating a genuine mixed-use development.Access to the site comes from the B, which links Longniddry to the A, Gladsmuir and Macmerry.Discussions over a sizeable housing development on the site have been ongoing for a number of years.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee approved plans for nearly  homes, including affordable housing for the over-s, on the site in the summer of .Work began on the site last year, shortly before the coronavirus pandemic hit.Initially, construction work was halted before developers ed, with the housebuilding now well under way.According to the developer, the latest scheme will result in the reuse of ldquoa signicant cluster of vacant listed buildings, providing enterprise and employment opportunities.A planning statement submitted with the application, which was submitted to East Lothian Council in  by Redhouse Capital Ltd and Socially Conscious Capital, notes: ldquoThe overall vision for the steading development is to create a local centre and hub for the Longniddry South development, supporting the vision for an exemplary and beautul village expansion with a blend of employment opportunities, tourism facilities and local services not only for the new residents but also for existing residents of Longniddry.ldquoThe steading will attract local businesses, [including] people seeking a sheltered and attractive cafe.ldquoWe anticipate the accommodation will also be particularly attractive to artisans for studios and workshops space.Iain Stewart, chairman of the villagersquos community council, acknowledged that concerns about the infrastructure at the development remained.He stressed the importance of ensuring there were good links for both pedestrians and vehicles between the new development and the existing village, and also called for assurances surrounding the villagersquos medical practice.However, he was also keen to ensure people moving into Longniddry became part of the village.He said: ldquoIrsquove been in touch with the developer in terms of the new folk coming into the village and wersquore trying to produce a directory to go into the houses with village organisations and try to bring the new bit into the old.ldquoIrsquoll be going round the organisations and businesses and shops this month to get them to produce an insert that could go into a welcome pack for the new residents.

title: runners-support-musselburgh-festival-organisers-memory-sister
story: Craig Lowrie, , took on a running challenge after the family tragedy in , raising just over pound, for festival committees and the childrenrsquos ward at Borders General Hospital.His son Robbie, now , was appointed Braw Lad in Galashiels in April .But just two weeks before the start of the summer festivals, Mr Lowriersquos sister Donna, , from Innerleithen, a married mum-of-three, died in a car crash on the A between Galashiels and Walkerburn.Mr Lowrie said: ldquoOur family were so proud and excited for the summer ahead. Donna was so looking forward to following Robbie around the Border festivals.With no festivals taking place in , Mr Lowrie decided to run k in each of the towns Robbie rode in in  ndash Hawick, Selkirk, Melrose, Peebles, Galashiels, Jedburgh, Duns, Kelso, Innerleithen, Musselburgh, Lauder and Coldstream.His aim was to raise funds for the festival committees in each of the towns and for the childrenrsquos ward at Borders General Hospital, in memory of Donna.Mr Lowrie said: ldquoI ran myself but, by the time I got to Musselburgh, ex-principals, current principals and committee members were coming forward to run with me.ldquoBy the time I had completed all  festivals, I had been nominated for a Pride of Britain Award, received Community Champion Award from Galashiels Rotary Club and was presented with common riding ties and pin badges, which was all totally unexpected.For the Musselburgh k, Mr Lowrie was joined by Alison Elgin, president of the Honest Tounrsquos Association, which organises the annual Musselburgh Festival.She said: ldquoWe were delighted to be able to support Craig in his fundraising and very grateful for the donation we received. We strive to make each festival as good as it can be and as accessible to everyone in our community as possible, and all donations are welcome.Also taking part in the run were Katie McLaren, Honest Lass in  Dean Bosworth, Honest Lad  and Ian Ritchie, Honest Lad , who was appointed Chief Marshal for Festival Saturday, on his bike.Their route took them from Musselburgh Racecourse along High Street to Inveresk and Wallyford.Honest Lad  Aidan Maguire and Honest Lass Claire Dougal joined them for the final leg as they made their way to Fisherrow Harbour, where they were piped through the finish line. They then headed to Sizzlers burger van for breakfast rolls.Mr Lowrie said: ldquoThe welcome I received in Musselburgh was fantastic. I was well looked after by the Honest Tounrsquos Association committee. Irsquoll definitely look forward to visiting as a spectator in future festivals. The generosity of the public in each town has been phenomenal, as we raised pound,.

title: toilets-showers-gullane-bents-147-000-funding-secured
story: Improvements are being lined up for the car park at Gullane Bents, with fully accessible changing facilities planned.East Lothian Council is set to receive about pound, from VisitScotland ndash with the final sum still to be confirmed ndash and aims to encourage people to cycle and use public transport to access the site.The latest funding award comes after a successful bid from the local authority in the second round of the Rural Tourism Infrastructure Fund .Previously, pound, was awarded for improvements to the toilet facilities at Longniddry Bents.Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for the environment, welcomed the funding announcement.The depute leader of the council said: ldquoThis is great news for residents and visitors to East Lothian."Gullane is one of our most popular beaches and, as itrsquos on the John Muir Way, is visited by many walkers and cyclists throughout the year.ldquoHaving fully accessible toilet, washing and changing facilities at the car park will be a really valuable resource to visitors of all ages and abilities.Thirteen projects across the country, from Shetland to Fe, have been recommended for approval ndash subject to conditions ndash to receive more than pound million to enhance the visitor experience.Managed by VisitScotland on behalf of the Scottish Government, the RTIF was created to improve the quality of the visitor experience in rural parts of Scotland that have faced pressure on their infrastructure due to the increase in visitor numbers.It aims to reduce the impact of visitor numbers on local communities and facilities, and create a more collaborative and sustainable approach to infrastructure provision and long-term maintenance of local facilities for the benefit of communities, as well as visitors.Neil Christison, VisitScotland regional director, was similarly pleased to see the project moving forward.He said: ldquoThe stunning coastline, sandy beaches and water sport activities are an amazing draw for visitors to this part of East Lothian and it is important that we support work to improve visitor facilities and the visitor experience, particularly when the tourism, hospitality and events industries are facing such a challenging time and remain closed under the current restrictions.ldquoWe all need to play our part in being responsible visitors and improvement works like these are crucial to ensuring our visitor destinations remain sustainable for years to come.ldquoThis funding will help the local community improve their facilities, as well as enhancing the visitor experience both for now and in the future when conditions are right and it is safe to do so.On what costs East Lothian Council would contribute to the project, a spokesperson for the local authority said: ldquoWe estimate we will contribute pound, from our capital budget for this project, although that exact amount may be subject to slight change in the design and tender process. The work does not require planning permission.

title: dalek-peppa-pig-display-east-linton-helps-support-foodbanks
story: Tinsel and baubles might be the usual decoration of choice during the festive period but the creativity of an East Linton couple shone through.Jim and June Forson, of Drylawhill Cottages, created the decorations with a dference.Using recycled materials, they created a host of recognisable faces, including the Dr Who character.Passers-by were asked to make a donation, with pound being raised.The money will now be passed on to East Lothian Foodbank in Tranent and Dunbar Basics Foodbank.

title: statutory-outage-torness-power-station-strict-coronavirus-rules-place
story: The outage ndash when a power station is shutdown for essential maintenance ndash was planned for the plant, near Dunbar, last summer but it was postponed with the agreement of the regulator to allow better arrangements and mitigations to be put in place to manage Covid-.The pound million project is due to get under way on Fridayand will run for about  weeks, with  additional contractors working at the power station.About  of them will stay in local accommodation.Tam Albishawi, station director, stressed that a number of measures were in place.He said: ldquoThe usual things will happen in terms of planning and preparation to make sure we deliver a safe outage.ldquoIn addition, the Covid situation has allowed us actually to change some of our mitigation.ldquoWe have invested in mass testing capability and we will be testing everyone involved in the outage every week.ldquoThat provides us with the ability to capture any asymptomatic iniduals and to reduce the risk of any spread.ldquoWe are continuing to review the latest ying of the lockdown implications.ldquoBeing part of critical national infrastructure, to ensure we get the right contractors on site to support the outage, what we will do is ensure every person who comes to site has had a negative Covid test before they are actually allowed on site.ldquoEvery person who comes on site must have a negative test before they can actually get through the gate.Two-metre social distancing is also in place at the power station, as well as thermal cameras as people enter the site.Mr Albishawi added: ldquoEveryone wears masks andsomeone is not able to wear a mask then we have additional options, like using the face visor and keeping that distance.ldquoWe have one-way systems in place to minimise the chance of the spread and they are all in place now on the site.ldquoFor the statutory outage, we have made sure these one-way systems are very clear for our visiting contractors. Those that can work from home are working from home.The statutory outage is taking place on reactor one at the power station, with , pieces of work to be carried out.Hundreds of contractors will be visiting the station over the next two-and-a-half months.Mr Albishawi stressed that not all contractors would be on site at one time and  of those contractors would be travelling from within  miles.The remaining  will be staying in local accommodation providers as key workers.The station director said: ldquoWe have split the working so that we limit the total number of people on site at any one time.ldquoEssentially, we have split the working to closer to - between day and night so that limits the total number of people and therefore the total risk of transmission.The reactor is on its second longest run since the start of generation in  and is due to reach its longest-ever run on Saturday. Last year, Torness generated .TWh of low-carbon electricity enough to power . million homes.

title: john-witherspoons-name-dropped-us-school-due-slavery-links
story: The John Witherspoon Middle School in Princeton, New Jersey, was named after the Rev Dr John Witherspoon, one of the founding fathers of the United States.He was born in Gford manse in  ndash son of the Rev James Alexander Witherspoon, the then minister at Yester Kirk who is buried there.John served as a minister himself in North Ayrshire and Renfrewshire and emigrated to New Jersey in  he also became president of Princeton University.He was the only clergyman to sign the United Statesrsquo Declaration of Independence. He died in New Jersey in  and was buried at Princeton Cemetery.The public school was named after him as a tribute to his achievements in his adopted homeland.However, the clergyman also owned slaves at his -acre country estate and lectured and voted against the abolition of slavery in New Jersey.Amid the Black Lives Matter movement and protests last summer, a petition was set up by Princeton High School graduate Geoffrey Allen, calling for the lsquoJohn Witherspoonrsquo part of the name to be dropped due to his involvement in slavery. It attracted , signatures.The petition was successful and the schoolrsquos board voted to remove the name.It is now called Princeton Unied Middle School, a name that will be used until a permanent name can be selected, which must be done by the end of June.Similarly, Princeton University voted to remove former university president and American President Woodrow Wilsonrsquos name from the school of public and international affairs and residential college because of his ldquoracist thinking and policies.Student protestors first called for the name to be removed in , with the administration reconsidering in the wake of the deaths of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor among others.

title: bid-helmet-tranent-baby-lowan-duncan-combat-flat-head-syndrome
story: Already, nearly pound, has been raised for Lowan Duncan, who has been diagnosed with torticollis, a tightening of the neck, and plagiocephaly, also known as flat head syndrome.Mum Rosanna Anderson will travel to Glasgow next month to seethe four-month-old needs the special helmet.She said: ldquoI first noticed it when he was weeks old, maybe five or six weeks.ldquoI noticed his head was a bit flat and noticed he was lying the one way so his neck was facing to his right.ldquoMy friend, she had the same with her wee boy and I messaged her and sent her pictures. She said it looked like the same thing and she added me onto Facebook group pages.ldquoI spoke to my health visitor and she referred me to physiotherapy at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children.ldquoHe got an appointment in the middle of December and they diagnosed him with torticollis and flat head syndrome due to him lying the one way all the time.The Tranent mum said the helmet was not funded through the NHS and she instead had to approach Technology in Motion, based near Glasgow.Rosanna,  ndash who is also mum to Charlie, Archie, Teegan, Frankie and Max, and step-son Aidan ndash needs to raise pound, for the helmet, which will be specially made for Lowan.She said: ldquoHis first appointment is to seehe needs it, his head is still really flat we have got  hours to pay a deposit of pound. Then, two weeks later, we have got the next appointment and need to pay the rest of it.Already, pound, has been raised, with Rosanna praising Tranent fundraiser Davie Martin for his support.Rosanna, who described Lowan as ldquohappy, smiley and a really good baby, who loves a sleep, said any cash donations could be handed over directly to Davie.She told the Courier: ldquoDavie has been brilliant. title: barber-shop-may-leave-prestonpans-security-shutter-removed
story: Alan Mulholland spent more than pound, putting in the shutter at thePrestonpans branch of his Eskquire barber shops after they were targeted by vandals last year.But when he applied for listed building consent for the change to the building, which is Category-C listed, officials ruled the pale grey shutters were ldquoharmful to its historic character.However, they did approve a separate application to be allowed to display the barber shop logo on the front of the shutter.Now, the shop owner has appealed to Scottish Ministers to overturn East Lothian Councilrsquos decision and allow him to keep the security shutter, warning that forcing him to remove it could jeopardise his ability to keep the branch open.Mr Mulholland, who also has a shop in Musselburgh, said that both sites were damaged by vandalism in January last year in what police confirmed was a ldquotargeted attack.At the time, he was advised by aPrestonpans community police officer to install the full- shutter, which is similar to ones used by other business premises in Prestonpans.East Lothian Council planners had suggested that an alternative grid or mesh which could be removed each day would be preferable.However, in a letter from Police Constable Walker Nixon, crime prevention officer, lodged as part of the appeal, he confirmed he advised the shutter, telling Mr Mulholland: ldquoDue to the previous attacks on your business, the removal of the external shuttering would leave your business vulnerable to further attacks, as in my opinionan external mesh, safety glass or internal shuttering would not provide adequate protection.PC Nixon also states in an email that incidents of vandalism on Prestonpans High Street, where the barber shop is based, are high.Writing in November, he repeated his advice, adding: ldquoIn the past six months, there have been  reported vandalisms in the Prestonpans area.ldquoThevandalisms tend to be at the centrallocations where people congregate.ldquoIn lightof the fact your business has been the victim of crime in a targeted attack, and from acrime prevention perspective, I indeed recommend that external shutters are necessary as apreventative measure to reduce the risk of any further attacks.Mr Mulholland said: ldquoI put the shutter in after advice from police and spent around pound, installing it and making it look good with the logo on the front.ldquoWhen I was told I needed planning and listed building consent, I applied and thought it would be straightforward.ldquoTo refuse because it is a C-listed building might have been understandable in the past but nowadays we have to adapt to the issues we face and I canrsquot afford to keep replacing windows.ldquoIt is not just the damage that can be caused, it is the disruption to business. In these dficult times, we should be doing all we can to support small businesses, not creating obstacles.Mr Mulholland, who took over the shop two and a half years ago, said: ldquoSpending pound, on the shutter for a small business during the pandemic was a big decision andI have to take it down I will have to reconsider my business in Prestonpans and look for another location, which would be a shame.The appeal is with the Scottish Reporter, who is due to visit the shop site.

title: musselburgh-grammar-school-headteacher-colin-gerrie-leaving-job-dubai
story: In a letter to parents, he announced that it was with "very mixed emotions" that he would be leaving his post at the school at the end of session  in June.He said: "I have recently been informed that I am the preferred candidate for the post of head of secondary at Greenfield International School in Dubai."Whilst I will be sad to leave Musselburgh Grammar School and will miss our fantastic students and staff, I will do so knowing that the school will continue to go from strength to strength."He said that East Lothian Council would now have time to recruit a successor in the months ahead which would allow for "a seamless transition".Mr Gerrie took over as headteacher at Musselburgh Grammar in February .He said: "The Grammar is firmly rooted in the local community. I have greatly valued getting to know and work with many people and organisations who do such wonderful work."He also paid tribute to colleagues, parents, carers and the community, saying: "Throughout my time at the Grammar, I have worked with many highly committed and talented colleagues."They have shared a desire to provide the highest possible quality of learning and teaching for our young people."I have also valued the support of parents carers and the wider school community."As he would be in post until the end of the current session, there would be "a continuity of leadership" amidst the Covid- crisis, he stressed.Mr Gerrie said: "It all goes without saying that the last few months have been unprecedented and not without signicant challenges."As I will remain as headteacher until the end of the current session in June, there will be a continuity of leadership as we continue to deal with the issues presented by the pandemic."I can reassure parents that we will see this pandemic through together."He added: "I look forward to working with and supporting all students in the second half of this school session."

title: letham-mains-primary-school-complete-ready-pupils-next-month
story: Letham Mains Primary School, which is at the heart of more than  new homes on Haddingtonrsquos western edge, was handed over to East Lothian Council this week.Next month, following the February school break, the school will be open to pupils, although it remains to be seen when youngsters will attend due to ongoing coronavirus restrictions.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, who represents the town on East Lothian Council, is the local authorityrsquos spokeswoman for education and childrenrsquos wellbeing and welcomed the impressive new school, which has been funded entirely through developersrsquo contributions.Councillor Shamin Akhtar at the Letham Mains Primary School site when construction got under wayMs Akhtar told the Courier: ldquoI am delighted that construction has been completed and Letham Mains Primary officially join our school estate.ldquoThe construction environment over the past  months has been challenging and itrsquos a credit to all those involved that they have been able to continue working safely to complete the building.ldquoIrsquod like to congratulate them on their achievements delivering these modern and high quality learning spaces.ldquoEveryone involved in Letham Mains Primary has been looking forward to this move and to continuing their work to establish East Lothianrsquos newest school within our community.ldquoIrsquod also like to say thank you to everyone at Haddington Primary School for their space and support as the new school was completed.Work started on the school in March , with Morrison Construction appointed to the contract following a competitive tender process.Work was initially due to be complete last summer but, due to Covid- restrictions on construction, the timetable was extended.Letham Mains Primary School is due to open to pupils next month with the building now handed over to East Lothian CouncilThe pound. million school features  classrooms, an early learning and childcare centre, a dining hall, dance space and a two court PE hall with retractable seating for performance and community use.Outside areas have been designed for outdoor learning, PE and play.The councilrsquos teams will now complete internal works including furnishing, IT and setting up spaces ready for the building to be occupied.Pupils and staff are due to move into the building after the February break, subject to coronavirus guidance, with the nursery due to open after the Easter holidays.Letham Mains Primary School is due to open to pupils next month with the building now handed over to East Lothian CouncilLetham Mains Primary School currently has  pupils across its year groups, with the school currently hosted within Haddington Primary School.Bruce Murray will be the first headteacher at the new primary school and was looking forward to welcoming parents, carers and pupils through the doors.He said: ldquoWe realise just how fortunate we are to be in the position of taking possession of a brand new school.ldquoOur pupils, parents and staff have closely followed the buildingrsquos progress over the year and we are very excited to be transitioning over.ldquoIt will be an amazing resource to have and we look forward to embedding the school in the community and growing the Letham Mains lsquofamilyrsquo.Eddie Robertson, managing director for Morrison Construction Building Central, had enjoyed the scheme, despite the challenge of the global pandemic.He said: ldquoEveryone involved in the Letham Mains Primary School project deserves recognition for coming together to create a fantastic new school despite the ongoing pandemic.ldquoIt does feel slightly strange to us all to hand over this school when the children canrsquot be there in their full numbers, but we look forward to all the children being able to occupy and benefit from the first-class facility the team has provided as soon as possible.

title: artisan-bakery-east-linton-given-permission-cafe
story: Bostock Bakery moved into the former Torness Motors showroom and used it as a production venue.Now, owners Lindsay and Ross Baxter have been given the go-ahead by East Lothian Council to allow people to sit and enjoy a iety of baked goods at the premises off Dunbar Road ndash once Covid- rules allow.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department gave permission to allow a change of use to include the cafe and an outdoor seating area.A council report highlighted that there had been no objections to the plans and stressed that the cafe section of the business would be ancillary to the existing bakery.The report reads: ldquoThe proposed change of use of part of the existing building for use as a cafe would be relatively small such that the internal public floor space of the proposed cafe use would only measure some  square metres.ldquoThe remaining internal floor space of the building, which measures some  square metres, would remain unaltered.ldquoThe proposed cafe use of the building, including its outdoor seating area , would be ancillary to the predominantly Class  business use of the building as a production bakery.Outside, there will be seven tables, with two chairs at each table for people to enjoy one of the products.The planning officer said that the scale of the outdoor development would be ldquoappropriate for the location and would be ldquowell-integrated into its surroundings.Twenty-two parking spaces will also be created, with four set aside for staff, and space for  bicycles.A supporting statement included in the planning application from Bostock Bakery, which also has premises in North Berwick, highlighted the benefits of the scheme.It reads: ldquoWhen Bostock Bakery took on the building, their aim was to use it solely as a production bakery to provide goods to their already-successful outlet in North Berwick, but soon after opening they began to receive an increasing number of visits from people enquiringthey could buy direct it was then that they decided to introduce a small counter space to sell direct from the bakery.ldquoSince this time, the bakery has increased in popularity to become a well-respected part of the community of East Linton, serving both locals and visitors from further afield.ldquoAs part of their commitment to remain in East Linton, Bostock are seeking to invest in improvements to the site and to regularise the use of the building for serving food and drink, although this will remain supplementary to use of the space as production bakery.

title: outdoor-activities-project-venturing-receives-2-000-boost
story: The not-for-profit company, based on the outskirts of Tranent, near Windygoul, offers outdoor activities, from water sports to rock climbing, bushcraft and school holiday provision.The profit it makes from its activities goes towards making sure projects are available for people who cannot access them, such as families who have children with additional support needs or are living with financial hardship, as well as other socially disadvantaged people.It received pound,. from lsquoThe Big Co-op Payoutrsquo through the Co-op Local Community Fund, which has now started its latest round of funding and includes several East Lothian groups and charities.Co-op members select a group as their cause and, every time they buy Co-op-branded products, a portion of the sale will go towards their selected cause the more members that select the cause and the more products they buy, the more money it will receive.The money Venturing Out received from the Co-op went towards its additional support needs programme, which is in its third year and mainly funded by East Lothian Council.The programme allows those with additional needs and their families to enjoy an outdoor activity together, something that has proven vital in recent months.Antony Stone, operations director, said: ldquoGiven the recent events of the pandemic, all funding is most welcome to help us deliver our community projects.ldquoFor many of our families, these activities were the only opportunity to get out and about with the whole family to take part in organised activity. Mental health and wellbeing have been affecting many during these tough times and the feedback from our sessions is what drives us.His colleague Claire Mackenzie stressed the importance of the additional support needs programme, adding that for some families it was ldquoalmost a sense of relief to be able to take part in an activity again, especially during the coronavirus pandemic, which has seen many people stay at home for the past  months.Venturing Out was forced to close last March due to lockdown and was finally able to reopen last July, with enhanced regulations and measures in place ndash it is currently closed again.Despite lockdown,  was a very positive year for the company.Since it reopened, it has run more than  sessions as well as  parent sessions.The number of families it works with increased by , with  families now on its database.Its summer programme was the biggest one it had ever run, running more sessions than the whole of  combined.For more information on Venturing Out, visit www.venturingout.org.ukAlso receiving money from the Co-op was Windygoul Nursery, which received more than pound,, and the third Tranent Rainbows, which got more than pound,.

title: dunbar-rnlis-reindeer-run-proves-great-success
story: The leboat crew pulled on their wellies, waterproofs and jackets ndash with novelty antler hairbands adding a festive flavour ndash last month for a special fundraiser.The group had aimed to complete  kilometres in the townrsquos Winterfield Park in their fancy dress to raise money for the RNLI.However, the event proved overwhelmingly successful, with the volunteers running a combined total of more than  kilometres ndash the equivalent of a marathon ndash and raising pound,.A spokesman for the RNLI said it was not quite as straightforward as it seemed, though.He told the Courier: ldquoJust as we were heading up to Winterfield Park, the pagers went off.ldquoThat sent some of the crew starting their run early as they hot-footed it back to the station. As it was, our launch ndash to a report of swimmers in dficulty ndash was cancelled and we could start the run on time.ldquoAfter our fitness instructor volunteer Becs got us all warmed up, we ran laps of the park. We then trotted up and down High Street ndash to the bemusement of some shoppers!The Reindeer Run is a traditional part of the RNLIrsquos fundraising calendar.A number of events, including Dunbar Leboat Fete and Dunbar Civic Week, where volunteers would be out collecting donations, were cancelled last year due to the coronavirus pandemic.Becs Millar, part of the inshore leboat crew, was delighted to say the Reindeer Run had been successful.She said: ldquoThe response from the public has been amazing.ldquoWe would like to thank everyone for all the support and kind donations we received.ldquoWe canrsquot save lives without it.

title: covid-scotland-takeaway-click-collect-lockdown-rules-force-today
story: The First Minister announced on Wednesday the introduction of six more measures in a bid to curb the spread of coronavirus.They came into force just after midnight, and comes at what Nicola Sturgeon described as a "critical and dangerous moment" in the pandemic.Speaking in the Scottish Parliament, Ms Sturgeon said:ldquoThe situation we face in relation to the virus remains extremely serious.ldquoWe must continue to do everything possible to reduce case numbers ndash this is essential to relieve the pressure on our NHS and to save lives.ldquoBoth inidually and collectively, these additional measures ndash in further reducing the interactions that allow the virus to spread ndash will help our essential efforts to suppress it.ldquoAt this critical and dangerous moment, please: Stay Home. Protect the NHS. Save lives.Fastfoodtakeaways, including many big-name chains, will face tighter restrictions as customers will no longer be permitted to go inside tocollect takeaway food or coffee.Any outlet wishing to offer takeaway will have to do so from a serving hatch or doorway.This reduces the risk of customers coming into contact indoors with each other, or with staff.Shops that have been operating a Click and Collect service will have to stop doing so under the new guidelines.Now, only retailers selling essential items will be allowed to offer click and collect.This will include, for example, clothes and footwear, baby equipment, homeware and books.All other click and collect services must stop.The First Minister said: "More importantly, for click and collect services that are allowed, staggered appointments will need to be offered to avoid any potential for queuing, and access inside premises for collection will not be permitted."Credit: Colin MearnsThe Scottish Government intends to "strengthen" the obligation on employers to allow their staff to work from home wherever possible.The law already says that people should only be leaving home to go to workit is work that cannot be done from home.This is a legal obligation that falls on iniduals.However, Nicola Sturgeon announced that shewill now introduce statutory guidance to make clear to ensure that employers support employees to work from home wherever possible.For all employers, the basic message is thatyour staff were working from home during the first lockdown, they should be working from home now.Guidance from working inside peoples homes has now become law.Ms Sturgeon said: "We have already issued guidance to the effect that in level  areas work is only permitted within a private dwellingit is essential for the upkeep, maintenance and ing of the household."No changes have been made for rules around outdoor exercise, however, Ms Sturgeon reiterated the "stay at home"regulations.The First Minister said: "This is intended to close an apparent loophole rather than change the spirit of the law. It will also bring the wording of the stay at home regulations in Scotland into line with the other UK nations."Right now, the law states that people can only leave home for an essential purpose."However, having left home for an essential purpose, someone could then stay out of their home to do something that is not essential without breaching the law as it stands."So the amendment will make it clear that people must not leave or remain outside the home unless it is for an essential purpose."This change will provide legal clarity to facilitate any necessary enforcement.Ms Sturgeon added: "I want to be clear though that this does not change the range of essential purposes that currently enable people to leave their house - nor does it, for example, put any time limit on how long you can be outdoors for essential exercise."But it does mean thatthe police challenge you for being out of the house doing something that is not essential, it will not be a defence to say you initially left the house to do something that was essential."At the moment, dferent parts of Scotland have dferent laws in relation to the consumption of alcohol in outdoor public places.However, from today,it will be against the law in all level  areas of Scotland to drink alcohol outdoors in public.This will mean, for example, that buying a takeaway pint and drinking it outdoors will not be permitted.Ms Sturgeon said: "I know this will not be a popular move."But it is intended to underline and support the fact that we should only be leaving home just now for essential purposes."That includes exercise or recreation but not simple socialising."And when you do leave the home, you should only meet one person from another household, in a group no bigger than two people."I know this is a hard message - and it is not one I want to be sending - but it is vital to reduce the risk of the virus spreading."

title: discover-new-ways-enjoy-burns-night-home
story: The GlenlivetThe Glenlivet is committed to brightening up Alternate Burns Night celebrations, inviting you to introduce a new flair to the proceedings and think outside the box with original twists on not just the traditional Burns Supper but the good auld Scotch drink itself that accompanies it.At The Glenlivet, they always uphold the importance of their own heritage as a brand and their place in Scottish history and whisky production. That said, The Glenlivet also embrace the notion of lsquoOriginal by Traditionrsquo, a concept which looks toward the positioning of our national drink and ourselves as whisky drinkers, always willing to break down conventions of what a single malt should be and focusing more on what it can be.George Smith, began as an illicit distiller in the Livet Valley with his Glenlivet whisky that quickly became highly regarded ndash one fan being King George IV, who requested a drop of the illicit dram during his royal visit to Scotland in . title: covid-scotland-uk-close-travel-corridors-monday
story: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has orderedfrom am on Monday, to protect the UK against new coronavirus strains, ending the quarantine exemption for arrivals from selected nations.Mr Johnson said: "Yesterday we announced that wersquore banning flights from South America and Portugal and to protect us against the risk from as-yet-unidentied strains we will also temporarily close all travel corridors from amon Monday."Following conversations with the devolved administrations, we will act together so this applies across the whole of the UK."This means that passengers travelling to Scotland from outside the UK will be required to isolate for ten days on .Passengers must also have a valid negative Covid test result, which was taken no more than three days before the scheduled time of departure.The public have been reminded that travel to or from Scotland without a reasonable excuse is not permitted.Heres what you need to know:Yes, but anyone flying into the country from title: schools-reopening-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-give-covid-statement-scottish-parliament
story: The First Minister will make an announcement in the Scottish Parliament on Tuesday, following a meeting of Cabinet to discuss the issue.However, the Education Secretary, John Swinney, previously hinted that it would be a ldquotall order for schools toon February , hinting that the current arrangements could be extended given the current prevalence of the virus.Asked last week about theat the start of February, Mr Swinney told the BBCrsquos Good Morning Scotland programme: "I think thats a tall order to be honest."He added: "The government will look at these questions at the Cabinet on Tuesday and the First Minister will give an update to parliament.ldquoBut the virus is still at a very high level in general within society and we took the view that we had to have the level of community transmission suppressed to enable us to protect the NHS."Currently, the majority of lessons are being provided online from home.Some vulnerable pupils and children of key workers are able to attend school.The Deputy First Minister made the comments following a number of reported problems last week with Microsoft Teams ndash the software used for online learning.He told the BBC programme: "I accept remote learning is a real challenge, particularly for parents who are working as well, but generally its got off to a very good start."He added: "The services have been up and running well since Tuesday and weve seen a very signicant increase in the usage of Microsoft Teams, which I think illustrates that the teaching profession has spent a great deal more time delivering live learning to young people."

story: Official data from the Scottish Government shows that , positive cases were recorded between January  and January .That equates to an average of around . cases being confirmed every minute during the week.This figure is down, however, on the previous week. Figures show that between January  to January , there were , confirmed cases ndash around . positive results every minute.Scottish Government statistics also show that more people are now in hospital with coronavirus than at any time during the pandemic.A total of, new cases of coronavirus were recordedin the past  hours and no new deaths of people who tested positive for Covid- in the last  days.The number of new infections is  below the , announced on Saturday and is the lowest since December  ndash although there tend to be fewer cases recorded at the weekend.But the number of patients with recently confirmed coronavirus continues to reach record levels ndash increasing daily since Christmas Day, when there were  people in hospital.As of Saturday evening, Scotlandrsquos hospitals were treating , infected patients,  of whom were in an intensive care unit .An additional  coronavirus patients have been admitted since the previous day, with two more in ICU wards.It comes as tougher lockdown restrictions were brought into force in Scotland on Saturday to combat the rapidly spreading strain of Covid.In response to what the First Minister called an ldquoextremely serious situation, further measures have been brought in to stop the spread of coronavirus and limit non-essential contact.People who live in a Level  area ndash currently all of mainland Scotland ndash should not leave or remain outside their home, except for essential purposes.Working from home has become a default position for all businesses through statutory guidance and services, and only those who cannot do their job from home should go into a workplace.Guidance previously issued to only allow essential work to be undertaken inside peoplersquos homes has also been placed into law.Ms Sturgeon confirmed coronavirus regulations will change to forbid people from leaving home for anything other than an essential purpose and that police can challenge people for doing something considered not to be essential after they have left the house.Entering businesses to purchase takeaway food and drinks has also been stopped. Now, premises will need to operate using a hatch or counter at the door. Drinking alcohol in public outdoors has also been banned.Non-essential click-and-collect services are now prohibited.Essential services ndash including clothing and footwear stores, homeware stores, garden centres plant nurseries, baby equipment shops, electrical goods , key cutting and shoe repair shops, and bookstores ndash can continue to offer click-and-collect services, but must operate with timeslots.In a statement to Parliament, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Wednesday: ldquoThe situation we face in relation to the virus remains extremely serious.ldquoWe must continue to do everything possible to reduce case numbers ndash this is essential to relieve the pressure on our NHS and to save lives.ldquoBoth inidually and collectively, these additional measures ndash in further reducing the interactions that allow the virus to spread ndash will help our essential efforts to suppress it.ldquoAt this critical and dangerous moment, please: Stay Home. Protect the NHS. Save lives.

title: advice-people-received-covid-vaccine
story: All three vaccines approved for use in the UKprovide protection against coronavirus.As more people receive the vaccine, it is worth knowing what is advised for those who havehave had the jab.When does protection kick in for those who are vaccinated It is important to remember that, with all three vaccines, two doses are required to reach the maximum efficacy.Though there is some degree of protection offered after the first dose of the vaccine, it will not have full efficacy without the second dose - which can be a number of weeks after the first.Doctors recommend, therefore, that those who have had their first dose of the vaccine simply act as though they didnrsquot - that is to say, continue following the same precautions as before by staying home, keeping a distance from others and practicing good hand hygiene.Even the first dose of the vaccine will take at least seven days, possibly longer, to kick in, meaning even the initial level of immunity isnrsquot immediate.Why are two doses required Booster vaccines are very common in the medical world, with the MMRvaccine booster offered to babies when they are very young.The first dose of a vaccine activates two types of white blood cell. The first is plasma B cells, which create antibodies to act against the virus. This type of cell is fairly short-lived, however, so without a second shot, rapid decline of these cells will occur, offering weaker protection.The second type of white blood cell created are T cells, which are tailored to identy a pathogen and kill it. Sometimes, these can linger in the body for decades, providing immunity from diseases that can last a letime.Importantly, the booster - or second - dose of the vaccine gives your body a higher frequency of these crucial virus-fighting T cells.Can I mix with family members or friends once theyrsquove had both doses Once someone has received both doses of the vaccine, they will have the full protection offered by the vaccine.However, there are a couple of reasons why it is not advisable to ditch current guidelines around social distancing and staying at home, even when both doses have been received.The first is that, though offering very high levels of protection, receiving a coronavirus vaccine does not offer  per cent protection against the virusyou expose yourself to others who may have it, therersquos still a chance yoursquoll catch it.If you have had the vaccination and catch coronavirus, your illness is likely to be far less severe thanyou had contracted the virus without it.Secondly, though scientists expect the vaccination to reduce the risk of people carrying and spreading coronavirus, the evidence is not clear-cut - meaning that, evenyou are vaccinated, you might still inadvertently spread the virus to others.You should continue to follow Government measures and guidelines around coronavirus until otherwise instructed.

title: food-eight-interesting-vegetables-add-repertoire
story: Evenyou arent attempting Veganuary or trying to go increasingly vegetarian for , now is still a good time to shake up your veg drawer.Its easy to get used to cooking the same old vegetables. According to YouGov, were massively reliant on potatoes, carrots, onions, garlic, peas and tomatoes - but with increased Covid restrictions meaning yet again more home cooking, a bit of iety at dinnertime can only be a good thing. And the more greenery involved, the better.Youll probably be aware of, or at least familiar, with this bunch, but how often do you actually pop them in your basket  Put these to the top of your shopping list now.... RomanescoOne of the most beautul vegetables around, Romanesco really ought to give standard broccoli more of a run for its money. Lime green and leafy, its fractalsare also, mathematically-speaking, stunning: theyre an example of nature perfectly reflecting the Fibonacci sequence. Excellent as a cauli substitute in caullower cheese, it will happily replace broccoli anytime youd usually eat it.. CeleriacWith its trailing roots and gnarly skin, celeriac can be a little alien-like and off-putting to look at or chop up, but once peeled and slowly braised with lots of chopped garlic and as much butter as you can handle, it is quite spectacular. Sweet, nutty and ideal in a wintry stew, wed also advise roasting it alongside carrots, parsnips and beetroot, to go with your Sunday roast.. KohlrabiIf you love your root veg, youll appreciate kohlrabi. Generally spotted in delicate purple or pale green, the German turnip cabbage tends to combine all the flavours of cabbage and broccoli, with the crunch and snap of water chestnut. Use it as the base for a grated salad , and you can also roast it, steam it and stir fry it.. FennelShave it raw into winter salads with orange slices and lots of olive oil, or remind yourself that quite a few ieties of veg rather enjoy being doused in cream and cheese. A fennel gratin, spiked with garlic, chilli and a snowy handful of Parmesan, will be fought over when served with roast chicken. Then chuck any fennel and chicken leftovers together to make a pie the next day.. KaletteKale can be a hard sell, especially when it comes to getting children to remotely appreciate its health benefits and slight bitterness. Kalette may fare better, what with it being so cute, frilly and purple-edged. Treat the same as its more grown-up sibling: fry in butter, stir through risotto, use to bulk out curries.. Shiitake mushroomsClosed cup, chestnut and Portobello are all very well, but the world of fungi is far wider and greater than that. Either experiment with a box of wild mixed mushrooms or go straight for the shiitake. Chewy and with bite, the East Asian mushrooms make for a substantial alternative to meat, and have a real umami hit when used dried too.. OkraOkra - also known as ladies fingers - is the seedpod from the abelmoschus esculentus plant, and originates from Africa. Suitable for low, slow cooking in stews, and also deep frying in a crunchy, spicy coating, it can take a real whack of seasoning.. SamphireIf youre lucky to live on the coast, you might be in a position to go forage these tangles of salty, juicy succulents. The fronds are crunchy, moreish and slightly reminiscent of asparagus. Ideal for pairing with seafood, like scallops, clams and sea bass fillets, dressing with lemon juice. You can even use it as a garnish in a gin and tonic.

title: mary-contini-spinach-fontina-risotto
story: The best risotto I have tasted has been on Burano, one of the islands on the north east lagoons of Venice.The secret of a good risotto is the correct rice, well-flavoured stock and plenty of grated Parmigiano and butter. A bit of Italian sunshine always helps.For the sauteed spinachg rinsed baby spinach tablespoons olive oil clove garlic piece dried chilliSea saltFor the risottog unsalted butter, plus more to finish tablespoon olive oil small onion, finely chopped stick celery, finely choppedmls dry white wine  litre well-flavoured stock, chicken or vegetableg risotto rice, Carnaroli or ArborioSea salt tablespoons freshly grated parmesan tablespoons grated fontina or asiago or any mild, creamy cheeseZest of an unwaxed lemonGood squeeze of lemon juice to tasteMethodRinse the spinach in plenty of cold water and squeeze dry. Warm the oil in a large frying pan.Add the garlic and chilli and sauteacute to flavour the oil.Add the spinach, turn in the oil and sauteacute for - minutes.Remove the garlic and chilli, season the spinach with sea salt and set aside.Prepare the risotto by making a flavour base.Warm the stock to simmering in a pot.In another wide heavy-bottomed saucepan, warm the butter and olive oil. Add the chopped onion and celery, mix and with the lid on leave to sweat over a low heat for  minutes.Raise the heat and stir in the rice. Leave to toast for a few minutes, stirring to prevent it sticking.Stir in the wine and cook over a brisk heat until the alcohol has all evaporated.Now, add hot stock, a ladleful at a time, intermittently stirring the rice, allowing the liquid to be absorbed before adding more stock.After all the liquid has been absorbed, stir in the cooked spinach and its liquid.Once that liquid is absorbed test the rice to see that it is cooked. It should be moist and fluffy but still have a bite in the middle.Take the risotto off the heat and beat in the grated cheeses and a final blob of butter.Add the lemon zest, a good squeeze of lemon juice and check seasoning.Cover the risotto and let it stand for  minutes to allow all the flavours to merge.

title: scottish-labour-feel-sorry-richard-leonard
story: Indeed Leonard was considered so invisible that his departure barely made it on to the front page of many national newspapers.Although fairness, passion and idealism are commendable traits, they mean diddly-squatyoursquore found wanting in the charisma department. Politics is a blood sport where wit and humour pack a punch, butyour man is floundering in the ring itrsquos time to throw the towel in. Irsquove no doubt Leonard has committed his le to improving the plight of the poor and creating a better world, butyoursquore a bit boring then forget it.Read More:Merton and Hyslop: Dont blame HIGNFY for Bojos rise to PMAndyou want evidence for the triumph of personality over principles, then look no further than to the current occupant of No  Downing Street. The list of Boris Johnsonrsquos misdemeanours are far too long to cover here, but itrsquos fair to say he is not exactly a man of high moral standards. For all his lying and cheating he could never be accused of committing the worse crime of all ndash being bland. Incompetent, yes, nondescript, no.But most importantly, Johnson ndash and also Sturgeon ndash are both protected by their respective invisible force fields, something Leonard seriously lacked. For Johnson, the force field is Brexit, for Sturgeon, itrsquos independence. Two colossal and immovable ideologies that have endowed both the PM and FM with electoral super powers and often gted them a free pass during scandals.Read more:Lennon and McCartney: Its time to let go of The BeatlesLeonardrsquos force field of socialism never stood a chance. George Orwell wrote: ldquoTo the ordinary working man, the sort you would meet in any pub on Saturday night, socialism does not mean much more than better wages and nobody bossing you about.On that basis, socialism lacks the appeal of Sturgeonrsquos stirring mantra of a self-governing people making their own decisions in their own interests. Rather than being regarded as a utopian dream worth striving for, socialism is seen as an outdated working-class mythology. Besides, who is working class or middle class anymore  Those waters were muddied decades ago by the rise of university education, property ownership and general affluence. Wersquore too posh to be proletariat.Itrsquos much easier to identy yourself as either pro-independence or pro-union, wave a flag, go on a march and fight for freedom, whether it be from London or Brussels.For the hapless ldquobranch manager Labour installs next, the binary choice of Yes or No will be the insurmountable obstacle he or she will face. Unless they can convince the Yes-No waverers of the merits of a ldquothird position on Scotlandrsquos future, a Herculean taskever there was one, no leader, no matter how decent or even charismatic, will ever attract a decent number of votes.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: claire-taylor-indyref2-public-health-must-come-political-ambition
story: Is now the time to stir up emotions and ide our communities in the pursuit of independence The SNP has ramped up its efforts for another independence referendum, announcing the creation of an Independence Taskforce ahead of members gathering this week to discuss the route forward for a second referendum.There is no denying the increasing appetite for an independent Scotland ndash some  opinion polls in a row have indicated a majority for ldquoYes. The latest Savanta ComRes poll ndash published January  ndash found that % of Scots would vote ldquoYesa second independence referendum was held tomorrow, compared to % who would vote ldquoNo ndash not including undecideds.However, should our government not be directing all its efforts and energy into vaccine distribution and kickstarting the nationrsquos economic recovery, not to mention preparing for the mental health pandemic which is already unfolding. Is it not churlish to speak of huge constitutional changes which will serve only to dominate discussions and ide communities, at this time when Scotland needs to be strong and unied in its support of one another Amidst the dficulties of the past year, we have heard countless positive reports of iniduals and whole communities who have gone above and beyond to help neighbours and complete strangers who are in isolation ndash a rallying effort which has not been seen since the days of war.At a time where poor mental health has become commonplace to so many, this lsquotogethernessrsquo has given everyone a sense of hope for the future in rebuilding our nation. But, there is a limit to Scotlandrsquos emotional resilience. Is now the time to bring up such a isive issue and push forward with a political dogma which could turn families, friends and communities against one another If we reflect back on the summer of , Scotland was riding on a high from hosting the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow. There was a great sense of pride felt by all ndash a perfect backdrop to what was to come in the Autumn.That year I began my media career as a trainee sports reporter at those Games, but it also paved the way for a future covering politics, and it all started with the independence referendum that September.I was part of the team organising Scotlandrsquos biggest ever youth debate ndash which saw  school pupils descend on Glasgowrsquos SSE Hydro to put their questions to policy makers. In the lead up to the debate, I spent weeks interviewing  and -year-old school pupils who had recently been given the vote and were excited to exercise their newfound democratic right for the first time.What should have been a fantastic experience, witnessing the next generation engaged in the political process, instead flagged up deep isions within Scottish society at the time. One conversation that has stuck with me was an interview with a -year-old girl who was born in Scotland to English parents and told me she was immensely proud to be Scottish but had been bullied by classmates for her accent and told she didnrsquot belong here. This was unfortunately a common theme throughout my interviews.In the coming weeks we should all prepare ourselves for keyboard warriors and self-proclaimed experts from both sides of the fence which will litter our social media feeds, andanxiety levels are running high as a result of the pandemic, let me assure you they will be triggered further still.Although the full economic and employment impacts of Covid- are yet to emerge,the looming recession is similar to that experienced after the  financial crisis, the number of people of working age suffering poor mental health in the UK would rise by half a million, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.I was pleased to hear Dr Alistair Cook ndash the principal medical officer for mental health ndash address the nation during the First Ministerrsquos Covid update last week, detailing the support on offer for those who are struggling during the current uncertainty.The Scottish Government is under no illusion that the pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a severe impact on the nationrsquos mental health and in response launched their lsquoTransition and Recovery Plan for Mental Healthrsquo this past October, to outline how they will respond in the months and years ahead.Before the pandemic, public demand for mental health treatment and support was already outstripping supply. A recent freedom of information request made by the Scottish Liberal Democrats found that one in eight senior mental health roles in Scotland are vacant, and across the country  consultant psychiatrist roles have not been filled.The Scottish Government is aware of these statistics and have rightly made strong commitments to addressing mental health ndash including increasing investment to pound million for  additional mental health workers by - ndash butthey are serious about tackling this ticking time bomb, then indyref must be placed on the back burner until Scotland regains its footing.Even amongst independence supporters, there is recognition that such a landmark vote shouldnrsquot get in the way of other priorities which need addressing. That same Savanta ComRes poll which showed a majority in favour of independence also revealed that health and the economy were in the top three most important issues facing the country, with independence coming in at sixth.Will the Scottish Government prioritise political ambition over public health at a time where Scotlandrsquos emotional resilience is already under immense strain I am by no means arguing against another independence referendum further down the line, but this should be a discussion for when this great little country is no longer on its knees and facing a looming mental health pandemic.
